Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned I can cram 8 chapters of fluid mechanics in 1 day.

I learned a lot of really interesting things about fluids, especially things in everyday life that you don't really consider. The control volume approach that you take throughout the class really challenges the perspective on physics that you learn in other classes. Although a lot of the concepts seem abstract on paper, it doesn't take a lot of looking around to figure out that the principles you learn are very applicable in real life, which was satisfying.
Navier Stokes, Bernoulli, Reynolds number

I did not learn as much as I could have in this class. The course has a lot of potential but the material and my interest in the material was massacred by the professor's teaching. 

You learn about the mass, momentum and energy conservation of fluids (liquids and gases) in different systems through control volume and differential equations analysis. The Bernoulli equation is arguably the most important topic in the course. You learn about how lift forces, drag forces, pressure, friction, etc all affect flows in pipes, over surfaces, between parallel plates and so much more. There's a lot of material covered in this course.

Rigorous introduction to fluid dynamics. Key takeways are hydrostatics, differential and integral governing equations, Navier Stokes solutions for specific fluid flow profiles, principles of nondimensionalization and important dimensionless groups, duct / pipe flows, flow between parallel plates, potential flow theory, external flows, turbulence, boundary layer theory, drag and compressible flow.
I learned a lot about fluid mechanics, problem-solving, and how to handle difficult examinations, as well as studying smarter.
You learn the basic methods of fluid mechanics, partially conceptual, but also a lot of convoluted proofs.
I learned more than I had ever hoped or wanted to. A lot of time management skills and independence. This class really goes in depth with all the topics covered (which is a shockingly large amount).

I learned all the main concepts of fluids, including hydrostatics, how to use control volumes to do analysis, laminar and turbulent flow, how to design pipes, how the property of viscosity affects flow, and how Bernoulli explains a great deal about fluid flow.
I think I have a basic understanding of fluid dynamics. I left with some confusion but it was taught basic aspects

This class presents a solid overview of fluids. We skip most of hydrostatics and the more practical engineering problems (i.e. correction factors for head losses in different pipe geometries). Prof. Gomez takes a very theoretical approach in his lectures (and on the open-book portion of exams), so make sure you're following what each term in the big equations (Bernoulli, Navier-Stokes) mean!
We learned about viscous, nonviscous, incompressible and compressible flows.
Vague understanding of fluid mechanics and the many applications it may be used for. Overall curiosity about the topic, but I still lack the skills to apply my knowledge.
I literally learned nothing from Gomez. I had to go back after lectures and learn from a dense and very confusing textbook.
I definitely learned a ton during this class and feel that I now have a fairly good knowledge of fluid mechanics that is widely applicable.
I developed an understanding of basic fluid flows both quantitatively and qualitatively.
A deep overview of Fluid Mechanics relevant to Mechanical Engineering.

Learned about control volume analysis; governing integral and differential equations for mass, momentum, and energy flow; dimensional and similitude analysis; internal viscous flows; external viscous flows; laminar and turbulent flows; dimensionless quantities (Reynold's number); potential flow solutions; and compressible flows. The class provides a very good overview of fluid mechanics and also helps develop problem-solving skills.
A lot of things about analyzing fluids.
The basics of fluid mechanics.
None.

I did learn a lot of interesting material, but I basically taught it to myself from the textbook and the class very slightly reinforced what I learned from it. The TA sessions were pretty pedagogic though.
I learned the basics of fluid mechanics, and gained the ability to analyze and solve problems.
turbulent and laminar flow
Learned fundamentals of analysis of fluid flows. Inviscid, laminar, turbulent, and compressible flows.
Learned an overview of basic fluid mechanics including hydrostatics, the governing equations, continuity and nvs equations, boundar layer problems, turbulence problems, and more.
Psets should be graded and help contribute towards overall grade. Get a different professor too.

The weekly problem sessions were HUGELY helpful, as were the videos we watched at the end of the semester about experimental flows. The office hours and availability of the teaching staff were also really helpful. The grading system of the course was a little stressful though, as most of the grade was left up to the final exam.

This course is simply too difficult. I have no problem with a challenge, and I am not one to care much about grades, but this was too much. When students go in to a test already feeling defeated, there is something wrong. I think maybe the course should be split into two semesters to make the workload more reasonable.
I would have preferred in class examples and notes to be posted to follow at home. While the material is interesting, I feel like it could've been more mathematical.

Do not take this class with Gomez!
Strengths
1. everyone was struggling together for the most part 

Weaknesses
1. Lecture was always all over the place. The professor would jump from topic to topic without really explaining what was gong on so it was very hard to follow the material. The professor's handwriting is also illegible! Couldn't follow his work on the board or his explanations. 
2. This course has a lot of derivations, variables, etc - sometimes the professor would write the wrong equations, notice his mistake, and still move on without fixing his error by saying we (the students) could just look in the textbook and do the derivations ourselves  
3. There was only one TA for the entire class and no office hours - which isn't very helpful when majority of the class needs help 
4. We had a section every Tuesday night (7-9pm) thought by the TA which was basically another class - if you actually want to learn/be able to do the p-set you probably go to the section
5. We had extra lectures some weeks in the semester - the idea was to finish learning the material early to have more time to study for the final BUT this was a huge MISTAKE since cramming more material into a week didn't mean we actually learned the material. People just got more behind so by the end of the semester you just have to learn EVERYTHING by yourself again.
6.  Exams were horrible even though they were open book/notes - literally horrible. i don't know what else to say about that. - partial credit was barely ever given on any problems. It's either 100% correct or 100% WRONG. 
7. The professor makes insensitive comments/remarks after exams about how the class did 
8. The professor doesn't really answer questions clearly

This is the most rigorous course I have taken at Yale. The pace at the beginning is relentless, with the professor demanding that the curriculum is complete before thanksgiving break. He claims this is a unanimous decision, though he intimidated people too much for people to raise concerns. Even when people did raise concerns, he was incredibly dismissive. This meant meeting three times a week (so an additional weekly lecture) + a two hour problem session every week. Altogether this amounted to ~4 hours of extra class time for the single credit per week, not even beginning to mention studying or problem sets. The grading schema is absolutely absurd - students are given no credit for homeworks, but will be penalized in the final evaluation of the grades if they do not complete them in a timely manner. Sometimes, we would have multiple problem sets due within a weeks time, and Professor Gomez had no consideration for breaks, often putting deadlines on the day we would return, making fun of students who were traveling or going home for break. Professor Gomez made us feel guilty for taking any sort of break or respite, even in some cases when it meant spending time with sick family members (as I know is the case for one particular student who went home over october recess to visit her grandmother who'd been diagnosed with cancer earlier in the semester). Of course, Gomez never made himself approachable enough for students to feel comfortable coming to him to explain such circumstances. In one case, a student discussed with me that she wanted to go to Gomez to ask a question about the midterm, but was too afraid he would make her cry that she chose not to. Students ended up cheating/copying from solutions manuals on the problem sets. This sums to mean that the entire course grade is determined by three exams, despite hours and hours of work put in on other assignments, which is altogether unfair for students like myself who are often putting in the work but don't necessarily test well. Not to mention that the distribution on exams had averages of 15% and 46%, with people getting zeros. 

If this course has any redeeming qualities, the textbook is actually decent. I highly recommend using both FM White and Fox and McDonalds to supplement study. Despite personal qualms, Gomez is actually a good lecturer. The material is rigorous, his approach is aggressive and he is unempathetic as a human being, but as a lecturer he has a strong command of the material and goes to great effort to pull things together at the end of the course, cementing an understanding of the principles of fluid mechanics. Despite my probably overall poor performance in this class, I feel like I will have walked out of fluids having learned the most of any of my classes this semester. I am afraid the grading will not accurately reflect this distinction, which is a key weakness of the class. Gomez' handwriting and accent also made the early part of the semester all that much more difficult to follow.

The course is not very interesting and generally seems like a lot of math for little conceptual understanding or problem-solving intuition and skills. The course is also pretty terrible for the number of students who are not mechanical engineering majors because it is never made applicable to other disciplines. There is also a great deal of challenging material that is just barely covered in class and there is little to no help offered outside of lecture. The professor's office hours are short and busy (and really inconvenient for people who have obligations between 3pm and 5pm), the TA runs structured review sessions that do not offer much time for specific questions from lecture that do not touch on the material that the TA brings to the sessions. Also for a class of this difficulty and this size (~50 students), there is usually more than 1 TA. Finally, when asked for peer tutors, our professor was unsuccessful in finding them until after the mid term of the semester. 
In terms of the structure of the class the professor rushed through material at the beginning to accommodate for his own travel time in the latter half of the semester. He required extra lectures outside of the given class time, and put quite a bit of pressure on students to move other commitments in order to make his extra time fit into their busy schedules. 
The course grading was also rather ridiculous. There were a number of problem sets to be completed throughout the semester and submitted on canvas. these problem sets were never graded, except for a note in the syllabus that said that if the student did not keep up with the problem sets this would be reflected in the final grade. While that grading scheme alone is quite unfair, the fact that the problem sets were never graded meant that the students did not receive any feedback on any work until after the first midterm. How is one to study for a midterm when they have no idea what the professor expects from them in their solutions? This also made the entire course grading scheme pretty brutal, as the 2 midterms were each worth 25% of the final grade, and the final exam worth 50%. That meant that as the students walked into the first midterm with little to no idea of what was expected from them, they were simultaneously laying 25% of their final grade on the line. 
Also, Thermodynamics should be a prerequisite for this class, but it is not listed as a prerequisite. While most mechanical engineering majors take thermo before fluids, or at least concurrently, it seems as though the mechanical engineering department, while constructing this class, has forgotten that students from other majors take this class, and therefore are not required to take thermodynamics beforehand. This means that students in the class who are already at a slight disadvantage because of their inexperience in mechanical engineering in general, are placed at a greater disadvantage when knowledge of thermodynamics is assumed.

This course subject is incredibly difficult, and the pace is very very very fast... especially at the beginning. It really throws the students into a hectic experience, especially since there is a lack of material that prepares students for the exams - there are no practice exams, homeworks are often irrelevant and ungraded, and the only way to get a good grade is to be lucky on the exams. This takes up a lot of time and is often difficult to prepare for.

The course had a weekly problem session where the TA ran through a few specific problems using that week's concepts, which was helpful. Professor Gomez ran good lectures but a lot of the theory and derivations could be quite lengthy and detached from applications. He did start to complement the lecture with powerpoint slides which helped understand the relevant big picture topics and concepts of the week. I also really didn't like that our grade for the class was completely based on the three exams of the semester. I would like to see homework be counted as a grade because this would both lessen the impact of the individual exams and incentivize students to be more thorough in their homework, and get better practice out of it. This would also allow us to get feedback on how we do problems. No homework feedback meant we started getting feedback after the first midterm.

Lectures were all theoretical and the psets/tests were practical. Really hard to bridge that gap.

Sometimes content was haphazard when taught (I.e. The class would jump around some)

I thought the lectures were good although very theoretical. The evening problem sessions were a nice complement to class time in that they provided actual problem examples. I wish Prof. Gomez had provided practice exams. Also, I thought the extra lectures scheduled so that we could devote the last two weeks to review were unnecessary. I would have preferred class running at a slower pace right up to reading period and having out-of-class review sessions. Also lame: our problem sets weren't graded. Prof. Gomez should get an additional TA or something so we know how we're doing on the problem sets.

The class breakdown of 0% homework isn't great in my opinion.  It means that we're only receiving feedback 2 times a semester and there wasn't really a great way to know what to expect on the midterms.  The lectures spent too much time on derivations that made figuring out what the important parts were difficult.

Strengths: Interesting material
Weaknesses: Poorly organized, hard to engage, no feedback.

Stop letting Gomez teach this course. He does not care about his students and his teaching style is abysmal. I cannot think of one strength about this course. Gomez has been teaching too long for this to be his teaching style and we are not the only students who have felt this way. He is a very smart person but let him stick to research and stop interacting with students.
There is so much material packed into this course that it just has to be fast paced. However, it was such a huge time commitment.

Prof. Gomez is the big weakness of this course. His handwriting is illegible, he writes all over the board in an incoherent manner, and skips around in his notes. The material is fast-paced and difficult but manageable.

I feel like a have a genuinely solid understanding of the material coming out of the course. The problem sessions on Tuesday night were very helpful. That being said, it felt a bit excessive at the beginning of the year when the professor had extra lectures and problem sessions in the same week.

I enjoyed the videos that we watched towards the end of the course which demonstrated elements of the things that we were learning in class. I wish we could've seen some of these throughout the course as opposed to just at the end. 

It's a bit harsh that psets do not count towards the final grade. I've never taken an engineering course where that was the case. I understand that it was out of a fear that the answers could be found online, but I feel like the numbers could've been changed from the text book problems or slightly adjusted in order to account for that problem. Furthermore, it isn't easier to find the answers to these problems than other engineering courses. Most students use the solutions to check their work, it is a helpful part of the pset process.

This course moved way too fast for no reason at all, we finished all the material by Thanksgiving for no reason as we didn't have the final any earlier so it didn't take any of the stress off of anything, in fact it made the class more stressful. The problem sets were too long and posted too last minute to be useful (not to mention multiple PSETs over fall break). I do think I learned more in this class than I did in some of my other classes though and I do enjoy the material. It should be structured more appropriately to be a manageable load for students who have other commitments as well.

The professor, Gomez, was easily the worst professor I've had at Yale. Fluids should be a good course. It is interesting and useful material for all types of engineering. However, he made it completely foreign and uninteresting.

Strengths: professor is very available for office hours and extra help, TA review sessions were helpful in clarifying the material covered in class, class generally does not use powerpoints. Weaknesses: material is covered at a pace that is a little too fast, lectures were sometimes disorganized making it difficult to see the bigger picture, professor's handwriting was often hard to read, homework being graded for completion would have helped, first midterm was too difficult.
Prof. Gomez would probably disagree with this but-- I thought a rubric of topics for the exam, or review slides could be very helpful in the review for exams
Need more organized notes.

The course material is very hard, which makes teaching it difficult. I did not like Professor Gomez's teaching style or lectures very much, as he moved very fast and often wrote the wrong thing on the board and asked us to refer to slides to see correct info. The tests were also very difficult, but that is less of a problem.
tests unrelated to homework, open book near impossible

Course teaches the important things, but I think focusing more on solving problems in class might make sense. Could be a class to make flipped with gomez's lectures recorded and problems solved in class.
Lectures need to be more understandable and not jump around as much
The money and emotional effort I spent on this class could've been better spent. Honestly, "Fluid Mechanics," more like "Teach yourself fluid mechanics 24 hours before the exam"
If you need it for your major, yes. Also ask around about prof teaching it

Not really, unless you have to take it of course. Or unless you're really passionate about fluid mechanics for some reason. In that case, you'll be fine, I just wouldn't describe this course as ~fun~.

AVOID IT IF YOU CAN -  the material is great/interesting to learn BUT not with this professor. If someone else is teaching, go for it. If professor Gomez is teaching, don't waste your energy or time. Except if you want to and have to take it for your major (RIP)

If you're taking this, you have to. If you're taking it with Gomez, you will learn a lot and probably still fail. I am sorry. Don't let Gomez get to you, mentally or emotionally. He has an ego complex of his own exceptionalism, and many of us believe he did things solely to remind us that we are not as brilliant/special/capable as Yale students tend to think of themselves. I was fully convinced I was going to have to drop the course, my major, and professional-academic goals as a function of this class. The course does get better once you dismiss Gomez' absurdity, and the material itself is actually really interesting. Good luck, we are with you in spirit.
I would not recommend this course to another student, unless it is required by major.
Do not take this class unless it is a required course with absolutely no alternative.
Most students taking this class dont have a choice.
Do not take unless necessary. Course not taught in an easy way and will require a lot of self-teaching

I initially was a BA Mechanical Engineering major who did not have to take this class. I switched to the BS for my senior year which meant I had to take fluids. Will it lower my GPA? Probably. Was it really hard and pretty stressful? Yes. Am I glad I took it? Yeah, probablyProf. Gomez is a good teacher who cares about his students and the intellectual challenge of a rigorous (and pretty math-heavy) mechanical engineering course was fun, at least in retrospect.

I mean if you're a Mech E sure it's probably necessary.  It wasn't a fun class and I didn't look forward to going to lecture or doing the problem sets.  You probably don't have a choice but if you're considering as an elective and you're applied math or something, I wouldn't recommend it.
No, not unless they had to take it. It feels humiliating to take this class.

You're taking this course because you have to. You're foolish if you're taking this course otherwise. Don't take it Gomez, wait for someone else to teach it since they will be more lenient with grading.

NO! NO! NO! Taking a class with Alessandro Gomez was the worst decision of my young life. This class ruined my mental and physical health all semester. His lectures were absolutely useless and he simply talked to himself while pacing at the front of the classroom scribblING gibberish on the black board that he expected us to decipher.  We were left to teach ourselves an already difficult subject out of a dense and confusing textbook. Before the semester started he gloated about failing his students and making tests so hard that the average would be below 50%. That honestly should have been my first trigger to get out of his class as fast as possible. When we all feared for our grades, instead of finding tutors for the class he asked members of the class to volunteer to tutor each other and just never followed through with finding a tutor. He also forced us to complete 12 PSETs that were not graded nor looked at but if we didnt submit would negatively affected our grades. This means our grades were based on 3 exams (25%, 25%, 50%).  These PSETs took several hours to complete because he deliberately chose the hardest problems in the book and some of the information we were not even taught and were not relevant for the exams. The first midterm was essentially impossible partly because we didnt LEARN any of the information in class and partly because he refuses to give partial credit. The midterm also was not scheduled until last minute (like a week before) which he then yelled at us in class about not making time in our schedules last minute to hold it during the night instead of during class. Then, he proceeded to berate us in lecture about how poor our grades were. Maybe the problem is not us but his teaching?! On top of this, we were given almost no feedback for grades throughout the semester. He would only make passive aggressive comments in class such as A couple of you might fail. IF YOU ARE NOT ABET AND GOMEZ IS TEACHING THIS CLASS AGAIN, GO TALK TO COREY ABOUT SUBSTITUTING THIS CLASS FOR LITERALLY ANYTHING ELSE. Gomez is just not a teacher and doesnt care about any of his students.

Fluid mechanics is such an important subject so you should take this class if you're interested in the material. Be aware that it is a lot of work and you will need to put in time outside of class and outside of doing the psets to really understand the material.
No, I would not recommend unless the professor was switched to someone other than Prof. Gomez.

I think this year there was one student who took the course who wasn't required to for your major. Unlike a lot of humanities classes offered at Yale, hardcore engineering classes such as fluids or thermodynamics are actually challenging. If you take this course without expecting it will be tough and time consuming, you will do very poorly. You'll also learn a lot of useful information.
RUN AWAY!!!!!!!!

The material covered in this course clearly provides me with foundational knowledge which will be important in the context of engineering. So although it is not absolutely required for mechanical engineering majors, I would recommend that you take it.
This course consumed my entire semester and not in a good way. It is required though and I did learn a lot.
Not with Gomez.

Fluid mechanics is a very interesting subject, and the class will definitely help you improve your problem-solving skills. If you are taking it with Professor Gomez, just be ready for a very difficult semester. He means well and is very knowledgeable on the subject, but it is often difficult to keep up in lecture because he moves very quickly and jumps around a lot. He is also known for making tests brutally difficult, so don't be discouraged if you don't do that well on the first midterm; everything is curved. Just make sure you keep up with the material and go to the professor or TA if you need extra help.

If you're an engineer, definitely! Not as brutal as some people make it to be. It's also a prerequisite for a bunch of stuff so I think taking it earlier on might be a good idea, especially if you're ABET.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Well, I would say do NOT take it. I even feel guilty to be so mean towards a professor, but I really learned absolutely nothing.
Could have been a great course. Hopefully Professor Gomez will learn and provide better notes but don't count on it.
Only take this if you have to
Not unless they have to take it.

yes, because you have to take it.  Prepare for tests that are unrelated to homeworks.  the class is relatively fair, but it will require a lot of work to do well and the curve is harsh.  people in this class come from all skill levels so be prepared for that as well.
Probably don't have a choice. Course is definitely very hard, but you will learn fluid mechanics.
Wouldnt recommend, but you probably have to take it
